title: Korean Food Words & Flavors
objectives: Name staple Korean foods and drinks
Talk about taste with key adjectives
context: Food is central in Korean culture—knowing dishes helps you order confidently.
Describing flavors with simple adjectives goes a long way.
You can mix food nouns with 맛있어요/없어요 and other adjectives to react naturally.

sentences.english: Ramen is a bit spicy but tasty.
This soup is a little bland.

explanation: 맛있어요 = It's tasty. 맛없어요 = It's not tasty. Add 정말/진짜/너무 to intensify: 정말 맛있어요!
맵다 (to be spicy) conjugates to 매워요. Many Korean dishes are 맵고 짜요 (spicy and salty) but balanced.
밥 can mean 'rice' or 'meal.' 밥 먹었어요? often means 'Have you eaten? / How are you?'.
Use 조금 (a little) or 아주/정말 (very) before adjectives: 조금 매워요, 아주 맛있어요.
Add 은/는 to highlight contrast: 불고기는 안 매워요, 하지만 김치는 매워요.

messages.speaker: 민호
messages.korean: 안녕하세요! 오늘 밥 먹어요? 비빔밥 좋아해요?
messages.english: Hello! Are you eating rice today? Do you like bibimbap?
messages.romanization: annyeonghaseyo! oneul bap meogeoyo? bibimbap joahaeyo?

messages.speaker: 동현
messages.english: Yes, bibimbap is tasty. Kimchi is tasty too.

messages.speaker: 동현
messages.korean: 매워요. 불고기는 안 매워요. 불고기 맛있어요.
messages.english: It's spicy. Bulgogi isn't spicy. Bulgogi is tasty.
messages.romanization: maewoyo. bulgogineun an maewoyo. bulgogi masisseoyo.

messages.speaker: 동현
messages.english: The ramen isn't bland. There's water too.

messages.speaker: 민호
messages.english: Do you have soju? Is soju tasty?

messages.speaker: 동현
messages.korean: 네, 소주 있어요. 저는 소주 좋아해요.
messages.english: Yes, we have soju. I like soju.
messages.romanization: ne, soju isseoyo. jeoneun soju joahaeyo.
